importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The 12-year span from the assault in 2013 to the 2025 sentencing highlights systemic failures in prosecuting campus sexual assaults and the prolonged emotional trauma for victims.

keyTakeAways: A man named Ian Cleary was convicted of second-degree sexual assault for attacking a woman, Shannon Keeler, at Gettysburg College in 2013.
Cleary sent a Facebook message in 2019 saying 'So I raped you,' which re-traumatized the victim and prompted renewed legal action.
The case took nearly 12 years to reach resolution, with prosecutors initially reluctant to file charges due to campus assault case complexities.
Cleary was extradited from France in 2024 after being detained on a vagrancy charge, showing the difficulty in tracking down offenders in the global digital age.
The victim, Shannon Keeler, described how the justice system failed her initially, with evidence destroyed and charges delayed, but ultimately delivered accountability.
The judge sentenced Cleary to two to four years in prison, citing his guilty plea, remorse, and history of mental illness, which was below state guidelines.
Cleary's statement of commitment to mental health treatment reflects a broader issue of accountability and rehabilitation in sexual assault cases.
The case illustrates how systemic failures in campus sexual assault cases — including evidence destruction and prosecutorial reluctance — perpetuate injustice for victims.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A man named Ian Cleary was sentenced to two to four years in prison in 2025 after being extradited from France and convicted of second-degree sexual assault for attacking Shannon Keeler at Gettysburg College in 2013. The case, which had been dormant for over a decade, gained momentum after Cleary sent a Facebook message in 2019 stating 'So I raped you,' prompting Keeler to renew her efforts with law enforcement. Prosecutors had long been reluctant to file charges in campus sexual assault cases, and key evidence was destroyed over time. The victim, Shannon Keeler, described years of trauma and a sense of betrayal by the justice system, which failed to act despite her initial report. Cleary, who had a history of mental illness and lived in Silicon Valley before moving abroad, pleaded guilty and expressed remorse. The judge, Senior Judge Kevin Hess, acknowledged the horrific nature of the crime and recognized Cleary’s remorse and admission of guilt, resulting in a sentence below state guidelines. This case underscores the systemic failures in how sexual assault cases — particularly on college campuses — are handled, including delayed prosecution, loss of evidence, and lack of accountability.
title: Man Sentenced in Long-Dormant Campus Sexual Assault Case After Facebook Message Reopens Wounds
